articles.headline: Trump and U.S. Chamber of Commerce Pull No Punches on Trade Policy
articles.snippet: Differences over trade policies have led to an acrimonious relationship between the business association and the presumptive Republican nominee.
articles.abstract: Differences over trade policies have led to an acrimonious relationship between the business association and the presumptive Republican nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, Thomas J. Donohue, the feisty chief executive of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, noted — without naming names — that there were “loud voices” this election season who talked about walling off America from talent and trade. He called that position “morally wrong and politically stupid.”

articles.headline: Pokémon Go Brings Augmented Reality to a Mass Audience
articles.snippet: The smartphone game shows how a new technology can break through from niche toy for early adopters to go mainstream.
articles.abstract: The smartphone game shows how a new technology can break through from niche toy for early adopters to go mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There are video games that go viral overnight, causing people to coop themselves up in their homes for days to play.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Future of Natural Gas Hinges on Stanching Methane Leaks
articles.snippet: Southwestern Energy is leading an industry group that aims to cut methane leakage to less than 1 percent of national gas production.
articles.abstract: Southwestern Energy is leading an industry group that aims to cut methane leakage to less than 1 percent of national gas production.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Ark. — In the energy business, natural gas is supposed to be one of the good guys — the cleaner-burning fossil fuel that can help wean the world from dirty coal during the transition to a low-carbon future.

articles.headline: In New York, a Falling Market for Trophy Homes in the Sky
articles.snippet: The market for real estate costing $10 million or more has been flooded just as market turmoil and government regulation have discouraged wealthy buyers.
articles.abstract: The market for real estate costing $10 million or more has been flooded just as market turmoil and government regulation have discouraged wealthy buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York City’s ultraluxury real estate frenzy — with its sky-piercing condominium towers and $100 million price tags — has finally come to an end.

articles.headline: Investors Scan the Murky Waters of Britain’s Future
articles.snippet: As Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, proclaims a commitment to global free trade, many are skeptical of prospects while alienated from European trading partners.
articles.abstract: As Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, proclaims a commitment to global free trade, many are skeptical of prospects while alienated from European trading partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Running Britain right now is not unlike steering a battered corporation.

articles.headline: Dallas Police Chief, David O. Brown, Is Calm at Center of Crisis
articles.snippet: In the aftermath of the police shootings in Dallas, Chief Brown’s public appearances have helped ease tensions in the city and the nation.
articles.abstract: In the aftermath of the police shootings in Dallas, Chief Brown’s public appearances have helped ease tensions in the city and the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — He was hurting, self-effacing and, as he put it, a little fried. At a news conference on Monday, he spoke about the crisis facing law enforcement, his experience as a black man in Texas, guns and division, and what kept him going — “God’s grace and his sweet, tender mercies, just to be quite honest with you.”
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Alan Blinder and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Obama Tells Mourning Dallas, ‘We Are Not as Divided as We Seem’
articles.snippet: President Obama urged Americans not to give in to despair Tuesday at a memorial for five police officers gunned down by a black Army veteran.
articles.abstract: President Obama urged Americans not to give in to despair Tuesday at a memorial for five police officers gunned down by a black Army veteran.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — President Obama said on Tuesday that the nation mourned with Dallas for five police officers gunned down by a black Army veteran, but he implored Americans not to give in to despair or the fear that “the center might not hold.”
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Tribunal Rejects Beijing’s Claims in South China Sea
articles.snippet: An international panel in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior, deciding that its expansive claim to sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.
articles.abstract: An international panel in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior, deciding that its expansive claim to sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An international tribunal in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke on Tuesday of China’s behavior in the South China Sea, including its construction of artificial islands, and found that its expansive claim to sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.

articles.headline: Amid Grim Economic Forecasts, Cubans Fear a Return to Darker Times
articles.snippet: Recent calls to cut energy usage, along with the faltering economy in Venezuela, which provides much of Cuba’s oil, have left Cubans worried about fuel shortages and blackouts.
articles.abstract: Recent calls to cut energy usage, along with the faltering economy in Venezuela, which provides much of Cuba’s oil, have left Cubans worried about fuel shortages and blackouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — During the economic turmoil of the early 1990s, power cuts in Havana were so routine that residents called the few hours of daily electricity “lightouts.”

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Endorses Hillary Clinton, Hoping to Unify Democrats
articles.snippet: Whether Mrs. Clinton can also win over the 13 million Sanders voters will be one of her biggest challenges at the party’s convention and in the weeks ahead.
articles.abstract: Whether Mrs. Clinton can also win over the 13 million Sanders voters will be one of her biggest challenges at the party’s convention and in the weeks ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — After 14 months of policy clashes and moments of disdain, Senator Bernie Sanders endorsed Hillary Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday, clearing away the last major obstacle to a united front for the party heading into its convention this month and the fall election.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick, Patrick Healy and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: New Evidence on van Gogh’s Ear Continues Debate on Painter’s Mental State
articles.snippet: “On the Verge of Insanity,” opening on Friday in Amsterdam, shows previously unexhibited documents and artifacts addressing the artist’s illness.
articles.abstract: “On the Verge of Insanity,” opening on Friday in Amsterdam, shows previously unexhibited documents and artifacts addressing the artist’s illness.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Everyone knows that Vincent van Gogh cut off his left ear. But since that fateful event nearly 128 years ago, there has been continuing debate among scholars about the severity of that mutilation, which took place in Arles, France, in December 1888. Did he simply slice off a little chunk of his ear, or did he lop off the entire ear?

articles.headline: Child Care Expansion Takes a Toll on Poorly Paid Workers
articles.snippet: Early childhood services are meant to relieve poverty, but a new study says they can actually generate poverty in the predominantly female work force.
articles.abstract: Early childhood services are meant to relieve poverty, but a new study says they can actually generate poverty in the predominantly female work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carmella Salinas has worked steadily for 14 years as an early-childhood-education teacher, taking care of 4- and 5-year-olds at the nonprofit Family Learning Center in the hardscrabble community of Española, just north of Santa Fe, N.M. Even so, she rarely earns enough to cover all her bills, and has more than once received a disconnection letter from the water, gas or electric company. A few months ago, she arrived home with her 10-year-old son, Aaron, to find the electricity shut off.
